courseName: Done is better - Build What Matters

intent.oneSentence: Train learners to think like problem-solvers, not task-doers: break complex situations into parts, choose the right move, ship small, test fast, and speak the truth without distortion.
outcomes: Separate symptoms from the real problem and understand before acting.
Treat unknowns as assets and restate problems until you own them.
Decompose big problems and find leverage points.
Treat plans as hypotheses; think in moves, not projects; use analogy and working backwards.
Simplify until it breaks; maintain multiple paths; choose with intent.
Define done as testable; ship the skeleton; build fast feedback loops; kill bad ideas early; measure what matters.
Pivot without drama; prefer momentum over comfort.
Use truth as a tool; build no-surprises culture; communicate unknowns; turn clients into partners.
Reflect like a pro; build a repeatable thinking loop; codify a personal playbook.
Leave with a system, not motivation.
nonGoals: Not a generic leadership course; delivery-first, test-driven.
Not tool-specific; thinking and decision frameworks apply regardless of tools.

bannedPatterns: references to the lesson instead of stating the answer
throwaway options (e.g. no impact, only theoretical, not mentioned)
options that are too short to be educational

Problem.definition: A gap between a current state and a desired state that requires action to close.
notes: Real problems are actionable; symptoms are what you see first.

Symptom.definition: An observable sign of something wrong; often confused with the root cause.
notes: Treating symptoms without finding the real problem leads to noise, not progress.

Understanding.definition: Clarity about what is really going on before taking action.
notes: Without understanding, every action is noise.

Unknowns.definition: What you do not yet know; treated in this course as assets that guide inquiry.
notes: Unknowns are your map; naming them is leadership.

Restatement.definition: Rewriting the problem in your own words until it is clear and actionable.
notes: If you cannot restate it clearly, you do not own it.

Decomposition.definition: Breaking a big problem into smaller, elemental parts.
notes: Big problems dissolve when cut into parts.

LeveragePoint.definition: A part of the system where a small change produces a large effect.
notes: Not every piece matters equally; spot the hinge.

PlanAsHypothesis.definition: A plan is a bet, not truth; it should be tested and updated with evidence.
notes: Plans are hypotheses; execution is the experiment.

Move.definition: A single, testable next step that advances toward an outcome.
notes: Replace big delivery with next testable step.

TestableStep.definition: A step whose completion or success can be verified.
notes: If it cannot be tested, it does not exist as done.

Analogy.definition: Using patterns from other domains to unlock new paths in the current problem.
notes: Borrow structure, not literal copy.

WorkingBackwards.definition: Starting from the desired result and reverse-engineering the path.
notes: Clarifies what done looks like before you build.

Simplification.definition: Removing everything that does not prove the core.
notes: Simplify until it breaks; then you know the minimum.

MultiplePaths.definition: Having more than one plan so that failure of one does not mean failure of the goal.
notes: One plan is hope; three plans is control.

DecisionAsSkill.definition: Choosing with intent using criteria and boundaries, not drift.
notes: Decision is a skill; you stop drifting when you practice it.

DoneTestable.definition: Done means the outcome can be verified or tested.
notes: If it cannot be tested, it does not exist.

SkeletonFirst.definition: Building the minimal structure before adding detail.
notes: Build the bones before you paint the skin.

FeedbackLoop.definition: Getting real-world signal quickly to adjust the next move.
notes: Reality is your best mentor.

KillEarly.definition: Stopping bad or wrong ideas as soon as evidence shows they do not work.
notes: The earlier it dies, the cheaper it is.

MeasureWhatMatters.definition: Tracking outcomes that affect the goal, not vanity metrics.
notes: Opinion ends where data begins.

Pivot.definition: Changing direction based on evidence without treating it as failure.
notes: Changing direction is strength, not failure.

Momentum.definition: Progress over time; preferred over waiting for certainty.
notes: Progress beats certainty.

TruthAsTool.definition: Using accuracy and candor as operating principles.
notes: Accuracy beats politeness in the long run.

NoSurprises.definition: Surfacing risks and bad news early so trust is built before problems blow up.
notes: Trust is built before problems appear.

CommunicateUnknowns.definition: Explicitly stating what you do not know yet and when you will know it.
notes: Saying I don't know yet is leadership.

Transparency.definition: Sharing status, constraints, and unknowns so others can align.
notes: Transparency turns transactions into alliances.

Reflection.definition: Extracting lessons from outcomes so experience becomes skill.
notes: Every outcome teaches; only reflection turns it into skill.

ThinkingLoop.definition: A repeatable process: understand, plan, move, test, reflect, adjust.
notes: You design your own repeatable problem engine.

ChaosToClarity.definition: Entering a messy situation and creating order through structure and priorities.
notes: Learn to enter any mess and create order.

PersonalPlaybook.definition: Your codified way of thinking, deciding, and delivering.
notes: Codify how you think, decide, and deliver.

SystemNotMotivation.definition: Relying on a repeatable system rather than mood or motivation.
notes: You leave with a system, not motivation.

procedures.name: Separate symptom from problem
steps: List what you observe (symptoms).
Ask: what would have to be true for this to happen?
Identify the gap between current and desired state.
State the problem in one sentence.
Check: is this actionable?

procedures.name: Restate the problem until you own it
steps: Write the problem as given.
Rewrite it in your own words (no jargon).
Ask: what would solving this look like?
If you cannot explain it to someone else in 30 seconds, simplify again.
Lock the restatement as the working problem.

procedures.name: Decompose and find leverage
steps: List sub-problems or components.
For each: can it be solved or tested independently?
Identify which component, if fixed, would ease the rest (leverage point).
Pick the first move on the leverage point or the smallest testable slice.

procedures.name: Plan as hypothesis
steps: Write the plan as a bet: if we do X, we expect Y.
Define the smallest test of that bet (one move).
Set a time or signal to evaluate: did Y happen?
If not, update the hypothesis; do not defend the plan.

procedures.name: Next testable step
steps: State the outcome you want.
What is the smallest step that could be done and verified today or this week?
Define done for that step (testable).
Do it; then decide the next step from evidence.

procedures.name: Working backwards
steps: Describe the end state in concrete terms.
What must be true the step before that?
Repeat until you reach today.
First move = the step that gets you one notch toward the end state.

procedures.name: Multiple paths
steps: Define the goal.
List at least three different ways to get there.
For each: main risk and cost.
Choose one to execute first; keep one as backup; park the third.
Revisit when you have new evidence.

procedures.name: Reflect and adjust
steps: What happened? (facts)
What did we learn? (insight)
What do we change next time? (rule or behavior)
Update your playbook or checklist with one change.

procedures.name: No-surprises culture
steps: Share status early: on track / at risk / blocked.
Communicate unknowns: what you do not know, when you will know it.
Escalate bad news with a proposed fix or options.
Never hide a miss until the last moment.

application: Given a scenario, choose the next best action from the procedure.
Classify an example (symptom vs problem; move vs project; testable vs vague).
Diagnose what went wrong and choose a fix.
Select the best leverage point or next testable step.
Translate a vague goal into a testable move.
criticalThinking: Trade-off: choose between two strategies and justify criteria.
Failure mode: identify the most likely risk if implemented wrong and how to mitigate.
System design: propose a rule or loop that scales and identify governance.
Second-order effects: predict unintended consequences and adjust the plan.

distractorGuidelines: Wrong options must be plausible, aligned with common mistakes, and teach why they fail.
Avoid extreme/absurd distractors; avoid none of the above.
Each option must be self-contained and educational.

lessons.intent: Establish that effectiveness, not smartness, is the goal; set the tone for operational thinking.
goals: Distinguish being effective from being busy or smart.
Commit to think, decide, and deliver as a loop.
See the course as a system, not motivation.
commonMistakes: Confusing activity with progress.
Waiting for motivation instead of using a system.
Treating the course as inspiration only.

lessons.intent: Teach learners to separate symptoms from the real challenge.
goals: Define problem vs symptom.
Identify the real challenge behind observable signs.
Apply the separation in one real situation.

canonicalExample.diagnosis: Missing deadlines is a symptom; the problem might be unclear scope, no buffer, or wrong capacity.
canonicalExample.betterApproach: Ask what would have to be true for deadlines to be missed; find the gap (e.g. scope creep); state the problem as an actionable gap.

commonMistakes: Treating the first observable sign as the problem.
Solving symptoms repeatedly without finding the cause.
Stating the problem in vague or non-actionable terms.

lessons.intent: If you do not understand the problem, every action is noise.
goals: Clarify understanding before acting.
List what you know and what you do not know.
Avoid action as a substitute for understanding.
commonMistakes: Acting first and thinking later.
Assuming understanding without checking.
Ignoring unknowns.

lessons.intent: What you do not know is not weakness; it is your map.
goals: List unknowns explicitly.
Use unknowns to guide inquiry and next steps.
Reduce the cost of not knowing by naming it.
commonMistakes: Hiding or avoiding unknowns.
Treating not knowing as failure.
Making decisions as if unknowns do not exist.

lessons.intent: If you cannot restate it clearly, you do not own it.
goals: Restate the problem in your own words.
Make it clear enough to explain in 30 seconds.
Lock the restatement as the working problem.
commonMistakes: Using jargon or someone else's wording without internalizing.
Keeping the problem fuzzy.
Skipping restatement and going straight to solutions.

lessons.intent: Big problems dissolve when cut into elemental parts.
goals: Break the problem into sub-problems or components.
Identify which parts can be tested or solved independently.
Choose the first slice to work on.
commonMistakes: Trying to solve the whole thing at once.
Decomposing into too many tiny pieces with no prioritization.
Ignoring dependencies between parts.

lessons.intent: Not every piece matters equally; learn to spot the hinge.
goals: Identify where a small change would have large effect.
Prioritize moves that address the leverage point.
Avoid spreading effort evenly everywhere.
commonMistakes: Treating all parts as equally important.
Working on what is easy instead of what matters most.
Confusing activity at the leverage point with busywork elsewhere.

lessons.intent: A plan is not truth; it is a bet.
goals: Frame plans as hypotheses to be tested.
Define what would confirm or disprove the plan.
Update the plan when evidence contradicts it.
commonMistakes: Treating the plan as fixed and defending it.
No clear criterion for success or failure.
Confusing planning with execution.

lessons.intent: Replace big delivery with next testable step.
goals: Define a move: one testable step.
Choose the next move from the current state.
Avoid project theater: long plans with no small wins.
commonMistakes: Defining deliverables that are too big to test soon.
Confusing motion (lots of activity) with moves (testable steps).
No clear done for the current step.

lessons.intent: Borrow patterns from other domains to unlock new paths.
goals: Find a similar problem in another domain.
Extract the structure (not the content).
Apply the structure to your problem.
commonMistakes: Copying solutions literally without adapting.
Dismissing analogies as irrelevant.
Using analogy to avoid doing the work of understanding.

lessons.intent: Start from the result and reverse-engineer the path.
goals: Describe the end state concretely.
Work backwards step by step to today.
Use the first backwards step as the first move.
commonMistakes: Vague end state (we will be better).
Skipping steps in the backwards chain.
Starting from today and hoping to reach the goal.

lessons.intent: Remove everything that does not prove the core.
goals: Strip the problem or solution to the minimum.
Find the point where it breaks (too simple).
Add back only what is necessary.
commonMistakes: Adding features or steps before proving the core.
Equating simple with trivial.
Not testing the simplified version.

lessons.intent: One plan is hope; three plans is control.
goals: Generate at least three different paths to the goal.
Assess risk and cost for each.
Choose one to execute; keep a backup.
commonMistakes: Betting everything on one plan.
Treating backup plans as lack of commitment.
Never revisiting plans when evidence changes.

lessons.intent: Decision is a skill; you will stop drifting.
goals: Use criteria and boundaries to decide.
Make the decision explicit (what we chose and why).
Avoid drift: defaulting without choosing.
commonMistakes: Delaying decision by asking for more data indefinitely.
Implicit decisions that no one wrote down.
Confusing consensus with a clear decision.

lessons.intent: If it cannot be tested, it does not exist.
goals: Define done as a testable condition.
Refuse vague done (e.g. when it feels right).
Use testability to scope the next move.
commonMistakes: Accepting done without a clear test.
Moving on before the test is run.
Defining tests that are too expensive to run.

lessons.intent: Build the bones before you paint the skin.
goals: Identify the minimal structure that could work.
Ship or test that first.
Add detail only after the skeleton is validated.
commonMistakes: Polishing before proving.
Confusing skeleton with incomplete or shoddy work.
Never shipping the skeleton because it is not perfect.

lessons.intent: Reality is your best mentor.
goals: Shorten the time between action and signal.
Use feedback to adjust the next move.
Avoid long cycles with no learning.
commonMistakes: Waiting too long before checking reality.
Ignoring feedback that contradicts the plan.
Measuring only what confirms the plan.

lessons.intent: The earlier it dies, the cheaper it is.
goals: Define a test or signal that would kill the idea.
Run the test as soon as possible.
Stop investing when the idea fails the test.
commonMistakes: Sunk cost: continuing because we already invested.
No clear kill criterion.
Treating killing an idea as personal failure.

lessons.intent: Opinion ends where data begins.
goals: Identify metrics that reflect the goal.
Avoid vanity metrics.
Use data to decide, not to justify after the fact.
commonMistakes: Measuring what is easy instead of what matters.
Opinion over data when both are available.
No baseline or target for the metric.

lessons.intent: Changing direction is strength, not failure.
goals: Recognize when evidence says to change direction.
Pivot without blame or drama.
Update the plan and the next move; do not hide the pivot.
commonMistakes: Treating pivot as failure.
Sticking to the plan when it is clearly wrong.
Pivoting without learning (same mistake in new direction).

lessons.intent: Progress beats certainty.
goals: Prefer a small step with uncertainty over waiting for certainty.
Use momentum to learn, not to avoid thinking.
Balance: move when you have enough to test, not when you have zero risk.
commonMistakes: Waiting for perfect information before acting.
Confusing momentum with recklessness.
No learning from the moves you make.

lessons.intent: Accuracy beats politeness.
goals: State facts and assessments clearly.
Separate truth from tone (you can be direct and respectful).
Use truth to fix problems, not to blame.
commonMistakes: Softening the message until it is unclear.
Using truth as a weapon rather than a tool.
Avoiding hard truths to keep peace short-term.

lessons.intent: Trust is built before problems appear.
goals: Share status early: on track, at risk, blocked.
Surface bad news with options or a proposed fix.
Never hide a miss until the last moment.
commonMistakes: Hoping the problem will go away.
Surprising stakeholders at the deadline.
No clear escalation path.

lessons.intent: Saying I don't know yet is leadership.
goals: Name what you do not know.
Say when you will know it (or how you will find out).
Reduce anxiety by making unknowns explicit.
commonMistakes: Faking certainty when you do not know.
Hiding unknowns to look in control.
Never updating when you do learn.

lessons.intent: Transparency turns transactions into alliances.
goals: Share constraints, timelines, and trade-offs with clients or partners.
Invite them into the problem, not just the deliverable.
Build trust through transparency, not through overpromising.
commonMistakes: Hiding problems to preserve the relationship short-term.
Treating the client as someone to please rather than to align with.
No clear communication cadence.

lessons.intent: Every outcome teaches; only reflection turns it into skill.
goals: Run a short reflection: what happened, what we learned, what we change.
Extract one rule or checklist item.
Do it regularly, not only after failure.
commonMistakes: Skipping reflection when things go well.
Blaming instead of learning.
No concrete change (only insights, no new behavior).

lessons.intent: You will design your own repeatable problem engine.
goals: Define your loop: understand, plan, move, test, reflect, adjust.
Document it in a checklist or playbook.
Use it on the next problem.
commonMistakes: No written loop (only in your head).
One-size-fits-all for every problem type.
Never updating the loop after use.

lessons.intent: Learn to enter any mess and create order.
goals: Apply the full loop to a messy situation.
Create order through structure (decompose, leverage, moves).
Leave the situation clearer than you found it.
commonMistakes: Trying to fix everything at once.
Adding process for its own sake.
Leaving without a clear next owner or next step.

lessons.intent: Codify how you think, decide, and deliver.
goals: Write your playbook: principles, checklists, and rules.
Include problem separation, restatement, moves, feedback, reflection.
Commit to one improvement in the playbook from this course.
commonMistakes: Playbook that is too generic to use.
Writing it once and never using or updating it.
No connection between playbook and daily decisions.

lessons.intent: You leave with a system, not motivation.
goals: Summarize your system: think, decide, deliver.
Commit to the next 90 days using the playbook.
Define one accountability or review cadence.
commonMistakes: Relying on motivation to sustain the system.
No review cadence.
Treating the course as a one-time event rather than the start of a practice.
